instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.PP0V9_SSD: What is PP0V9_SSD? PP0V9_SSD is a power rail that powers the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on Macbooks with soldered on storage and must be present for the SSD to show up. .
definitions.P2V7NAND_EN: What is P2V7NAND_EN? P2V7NAND_EN is a signal that enables the PP2V7_NAND power rail when it is high, which is a power rail necessary to turn on the SSD. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Touch Bar Question Mark Folder
threads.message:
Hello,

I have a MacBook that is stuck on the question mark folder.

With the motherboard fully out and charger plugged in:

20 volts on charger, 0.43 amps
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 13.10 volts

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SSD</SIGNAL> = 3.3 volts
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVIN_2V7_NAND</SIGNAL> = 13.10 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_SSD_HOT</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_HOT</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD_COLD</SIGNAL> = 0 volts
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

<CHIP>U9400</CHIP>:
pin 19 - <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_VCC</SIGNAL> = 5 volts
pin 20 - <SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_PVCC</SIGNAL> = 5 volts
pin 15 - <SIGNAL>P2V7NAND_EN</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

<SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL> = 3 volts

<RESISTOR>R9420</RESISTOR> pin 2 <SIGNAL>PICCOLO_VEN1</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

<SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH1</SIGNAL> = 0.5 volts
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_CPU_PH2</SIGNAL> = 0.8 volts



I tried holding option key to see if I can see internal storage, but keyboard doesn't respond. Not too sure why. Tried PRAM reset, doesn't respond either. Any advice?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Touch Bar Question Mark Folder
threads.message: Everything seems to point back to a <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> issue. Should I replace this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Touch Bar Question Mark Folder
threads.message: I found a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0.005 resistance to ground. Only 0.14 volts. Time to investigate..

pin 15 - <SIGNAL>P2V7NAND_EN</SIGNAL> = 0 volts

Hi, I got a nearly identical issue, question mark folder, keyboard not responding neither for boot selector nor PRAM, same motherboard, same missing voltages.
Did you resolve it with <CHIP>U9300</CHIP> replacement?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Touch Bar Question Mark Folder
threads.message:
Please, open new thread with your problem.
Same symptom doesn't imply the same fault component.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> - MacBook Pro Touch Bar Question Mark Folder
threads.message:
And was explained to you to insert the J9600 cap correctly!!!

BTW, no need to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Write directly on the Reply Box, down the page.
